utterances: Thanks, guys.
Thanks for the call, James.
All right.
Here's an e-mail we have from Jessica(ph) in Charlotte, North Carolina.
(Reading) I love ""Charlie Wilson's War"" and the performance by Tom Hanks and Julia Roberts.
Very disappointed to see the absence of this movie and the actors from the nomination expect for best supporting actor.
Now, I guess you have to take some solace in Philip Seymour Hoffman...
Does he get a nod every year?
He does.
He's one of those people, I think Cate Blanchett as well who got two this year.
Yeah.
Wasn't enough to just got one.
Yes.
He's a stalwart, he's a dependable guy - he definitely is it.
He generally deserves it too, I mean, he's a wonderful actor.
Absolutely and he did win a few years ago, as well.
Let's get James(ph) on the line, James calling us from Phoenix, Arizona.
Hi there.
I - my original question was about ""The Assassination of Jesse James by the Coward Robert Ford"" and I though I would do a little research.
I notice they get two nominations for Casey Affleck in a supporting role and cinematography, but the starring role is Brad Pitt and he didn't get a thing.
He didn't get a thing, but would you really say that he was the star of the film?
I almost think that Casey Affleck is really more the best - he would be the lead actor in that film, in my opinion.
I think he has more screen time and he certainly is more of the focus of the film.
We see Brad Pitt's character, Jesse James, through his eyes.

The reason I would rate Brad Pitt in this is because I hate Brad Pitt but I love the movie and I thought that he was great in the role, so I really think that he brought something that he hasn't brought to roles since his starring role in ""Babel""...
Yeah.
...for example.
Playing against type.
So, anyway, thanks for the call, James.
10 to Yuma.
Mm-hmm.
There's another example, yes.
Well, he - that film was sort of overlooked in a lot of categories, I think.

I think that's one probably people are going to catch up with on DVD and take a look at now and - that often happens, I mean, we see these movies now and there's this judgments of them now and then in hindsight we go back and look at them and say why wasn't that nominated?
Why didn't that win?
I mean, again there's an enormous list of movies that aren't considered, you know, the greatest films of all time, that never even got nominated for a best picture Oscar, let alone one.
I mean, ""Singing in the Rain"" was never nominated for best picture.
Impossible to believe.
It is hard to believe, isn't it?
Meanwhile, while we've got you there at Sundance, the last couple of minutes, what have you seen this year at the festival that's going to look good maybe next year?
Well, one that's coming out relatively soon, I will say that people should look forward, is the new film from Michel Gondry, it's called ""Be Kind Rewind."" It stars Jack Black and Mos Def.
And if anyone has seen other Michel Gondry films like the ""Science of Sleep"" and ""Eternal Sunshine"" I don't think they'll be disappointed.
It's a very Gondryian(ph) movie, if I can make up an adjective right on the spot.
It has its usual, sort of, his flair and his unique visual style and sense of humor and all of that is in there.
It's a very funny, very warm film, and if you ever wanted to see Jack Black cast in a role of Robocop, ""Be Kind Rewind"" is the movie to see.
As Robocop?

Yes, because the characters in the film accidentally erased all the videotapes in the video store that they work in and so they try to recreate the movie so that no one notices and they cast themselves the roles, so you see Jack Black as Robocop, Jack Black and Mos Def in ""Ghost Busters"" and the list goes on and on, and so it's very funny.
So I definitely recommend that one very highly.
Matt Singer, thanks for the recommendation and thanks very much for being with us today.
My pleasure.

Matt Singer is the host of the Independent Film Channel's news program and he joins us today from the Sundance Film Festival to talk about the nominees, including some of those who are snubbed and weren't nominated for this year's Academy Award nominations.
This is TALK OF THE NATION from NPR News.
I'm Neal Conan in Washington.
What a day to be in Washington, a good morning to recall a story about former House Speaker John Boehner.
He said recently that when Republicans vowed to move quickly on replacing the Affordable Care Act, he started laughing.
Republicans, he said, had never ever one time agreed on what a health care proposal should look like.
Today, we find out who gets the last laugh because despite Republican opposition, House leaders plan to hold a vote on a replacement plan.
Ohio's Jim Jordan is among the Republicans who've been leaning against it.
(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING)
We actually think this is the wrong piece of legislation.
Ask yourself a couple fundamental questions.
Does it repeal Obamacare?
No, it doesn't.
Does it unite Republicans?
No, it doesn't.
Every major conservative group's against it.
You've got senators opposed to it, House members opposed to it.
It doesn't unite Republicans and doesn't, most importantly, lower premiums.
So those are some of the questions on the table for Jordan.
Other Republicans are arguing they must go with this legislation.
NPR health policy correspondent Alison Kodjak is in our studios.
Hi, Alison.
Hi, Steve.
How is the legislation changing as Republican leaders try to get it through?
Yeah.
The leadership has been working all week to make changes to get people like Jim Jordan to say yes, I'll vote for this.
Earlier this week, they made some major changes to the Medicaid proposals in the bill.
One of those is to allow state governors to turn Medicaid into a single block grant, which means the federal government just gives them a fixed amount of money every year.
That would only go up with inflation but wouldn't go up as peoples' health care needs grow or as more people qualify for Medicaid.
Meaning like if there's a recession or something, people are not assured of the same quality of Medicaid care if there are more people in Medicaid?
Exactly.
Exactly.
They'd have to make some choices.
There was something about essential health benefits discussed last night.
What's that about?
So in the Affordable Care Act or Obamacare, there are a list of 10 essential health benefits.
They're sort of broad categories that include maternal and child care, that include mental health care and other things.
And then they're very well detailed in regulation.

This is one of the things that conservative Republicans really hate about the Affordable Care Act 'cause they say that requiring insurance companies to cover these things makes premiums higher, which it does because the insurance is better.
Every policy has to cover every one of these essential health benefits.
OK.
Exactly.
And before the Affordable Care Act, there was this problem of people not knowing what they got covered.
So last night into the night, they were really working hard to figure out if there's a way to remove essential health benefits from the bill or repeal them in the bill.
All right.
No.
Princeton, West Virginia.
That's our program for today.
Thanks for joining us.
To listen to the show, visit npr.org.

This is NEWS AND NOTES.
